title.children: Weekend cold snap to see temperatures drop, snow, hail and thunder

items.synopsis: The prime minister is putting aside his republican views to pledge allegiance to King Charles III to honour "the system of government we have", but believes the day will come when Australia stands on its own two feet.

title.children: Albanese says 'it's not up to me' to refuse pledge of allegiance to King Charles

title.children: Major cancer treatment centre in cyber attack, hackers demand ransom for stolen data

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Ukraine shoots down its own drone, and where to watch Father Bob's state funeral. Catch up with The Loop

schema.headline: The Loop live: US denies Russian 'lies' over Kremlin drone attack, Father Bob's state funeral, and royal fans set up for King Charles's coronation

liveBlogUpdate.headline: A cold snap will hit the south-east this weekend
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It's time to rug up if you're in south-east Australia, as there's a polar air mass from deep in the Southern Ocean which is about to deliver a bitter cold snap. Here's how ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders explains the forecast: "The early taste of winter will send temperatures as much as eight degrees below average for May, bringing pockets of hail and thunder along with the first snowfall of the year along stretches of the ranges. "While cold weather in autumn is far from unprecedented, this weekend will bring the coldest early May weather for three years." Here is the Bureau of Meteorology's look at the weekend ahead:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's how to watch Father Bob's state funeral
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: What's the link for the live stream of Father Bob's funeral today please? Can't find it on the St Patrick's website. - Faron. Hi Faron, Here is the link to watch the live stream of Father Bob's funeral from 11am today. The stream will also be shown in Melbourne's Fed Square.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Sydney cancer treatment centre allegedly targeted in cyber attack
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: A major cancer treatment centre in Sydney has been targeted by cyber criminals, who are threatening to release stolen data unless they're paid. Hackers have hit the Crown Princess Mary Cancer Centre, which is part of Westmead Hospital in the city's west. It's unclear what type of data has been stolen and how many people are affected, but the group is demanding a bounty of $100,000. New South Wales Health says it's aware of the threat and is trying to work out whether any data has been affected. You can read more about this story here:

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Napoli win their first Serie A title in 33 years
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Napoli have won their third Serie A title — and their first in 33 years — after a 1-1 draw at Udinese secured an unassailable lead in the standings. Napoli's triumph ended the city's long wait for the Scudetto since Argentine great Diego Maradona led them to two championships in 1986-87 and 1989-90. A second-half goal by Victor Osimhen secured Napoli the title with five games remaining in the season. As the final whistle blew, Napoli supporters rushed onto the pitch to celebrate the momentous occasion alongside the players. Napoli have 80 points, securing their position at the top of the table. Second-placed Lazio, who also have five games left to play, are 16 points behind.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ukraine says it shot down its own drone flying out of control over Kyiv
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Ukraine's air force says it has destroyed one of its own drones after it started flying out of control over Kyiv. "On 4th May at about 8 p.m. during a planned flight in Kyiv region, control was lost over a Baykartar TV2 drone," the air force said in a statement on Telegram. "As the uncontrolled flight of the drone in skies over the capital could have led to undesirable consequences, the decision was taken to use mobile fire groups. The target - destroyed!" The statement says the drone probably suffered a technical failure. The drone appears to be the one captured in the video below, which was filmed flying over Kyiv before being shot down.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ed Sheeran wins copyright case brought by Marvin Gay's heirs
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In case you missed this news from overnight — singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran has won a copyright case which was brought against him by the heirs of music legend Marvin Gay. A jury in a Manhattan federal court has decided Sheeran's 2014 hit Thinking Out Loud did not unlawfully copy Marvin Gaye's 1973 song Let's Get It On. Sheeran says he is "not a piggy bank to shake", and is "devastated" to be accused of stealing someone else's song. "I want to thank the jury for making the decision that will help protect the creative process for songwriters here in the United States and all around the world," he says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: US denies it was responsible for alleged drone attack on the Kremlin
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The White House has dismissed what it calls Russian "lies" alleging the United States was responsible for a purported drone attack against the Kremlin in Moscow. Russia claims the US was behind what it says was a drone attack on the Kremlin which aimed to kill President Vladimir Putin. White House national security spokesperson John Kirby says there is still no conclusive evidence as to the authenticity of a video showing the alleged drone attack. Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, without providing evidence, said Ukraine had acted on US orders when it launched what Russia said was a drone attack on the Kremlin building in the early hours of Wednesday morning. "We know very well that decisions about such actions, about such terrorist attacks, are made not in Kyiv but in Washington," Mr Peskov said. Kirby said the US did not encourage or enable Ukraine to strike outside its borders. "I can assure you that there was no involvement by the United States in this. Whatever it was did not involve us," Mr Kirby told cable news network MSNBC. "We still don't really know what happened." Ukraine also denied involvement in the incident, which followed a string of explosions over the past week targeting freight trains and oil depots in western Russia and Russian-controlled Crimea.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: News Australia is searching for: Queen Charlotte
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Netflix series Bridgerton is back, this time with a prequel about the rise of Queen Charlotte. But, as my colleague Jessica Riga points out, it's a "fiction inspired by fact", where all liberties taken are "quite intentional". Before you dive into the show, check out Jessica's piece below about what we know about the real Queen Charlotte.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Father Bob to be farewelled at public state funeral today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Father Bob Maguire, the Catholic priest known for his charitable work and irreverent sense of humour, will be farewelled with a state funeral in Melbourne today. The funeral, to be held from 11am at St Patrick's Cathedral in East Melbourne, will be open to the public but also live-streamed online. Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews has said the service will "celebrate the life and work of a great Victorian. For our state, and the whole nation". In lieu of flowers and at the request of Father' Bob's family, the Father Bob Foundation is calling for donations to continue its work. The much-loved priest died late last month, aged 88.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One more thing: Royal fans are setting up camp for King Charles's coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Locals and tourists alike are securing their spots for King Charles III's coronation, which takes place in London tomorrow. You can read up on the ABC's broadcast plans here. Until then, here are some fresh pictures of some of the most elaborate setups and keenest royal watchers:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The White House has dismissed what it calls Russian "lies" alleging the United States was responsible for a purported drone attack against the Kremlin in Moscow. Russia claims the US was behind what it says was a drone attack on the Kremlin which aimed to kill President Vladimir Putin. White House national security spokesperson John Kirby says there is still no conclusive evidence as to the authenticity of a video showing the alleged drone attack. Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, without providing evidence, said Ukraine had acted on US orders when it launched what Russia said was a drone attack on the Kremlin building in the early hours of Wednesday morning. "We know very well that decisions about such actions, about such terrorist attacks, are made not in Kyiv but in Washington," Mr Peskov said. Kirby said the US did not encourage or enable Ukraine to strike outside its borders. "I can assure you that there was no involvement by the United States in this. Whatever it was did not involve us," Mr Kirby told cable news network MSNBC. "We still don't really know what happened." Ukraine also denied involvement in the incident, which followed a string of explosions over the past week targeting freight trains and oil depots in western Russia and Russian-controlled Crimea.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US denies it was responsible for alleged drone attack on the Kremlin

props.alt: A middle aged white man in a suit and glasses speaks in front of an American flag

children.content: (AP: Susan Walsh)
The White House has dismissed what it calls Russian "lies" alleging the United States was responsible for a purported drone attack against the Kremlin in Moscow.
Russia claims the US was behind what it says was a drone attack on the Kremlin which aimed to kill President Vladimir Putin.
White House national security spokesperson John Kirby says there is still
no conclusive evidence as to the authenticity of a video showing the alleged drone attack

Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, without providing evidence, said Ukraine had acted on US orders when it launched what Russia said was a drone attack on the Kremlin building in the early hours of Wednesday morning.
"We know very well that decisions about such actions, about such terrorist attacks, are made not in Kyiv but in Washington," Mr Peskov said.
Kirby said the US did not encourage or enable Ukraine to strike outside its borders.
"I can assure you that there was no involvement by the United States in this. Whatever it was did not involve us," Mr Kirby told cable news network MSNBC.
"We still don't really know what happened."
Ukraine also denied involvement in the incident, which followed a string of explosions over the past week targeting freight trains and oil depots in western Russia and Russian-controlled Crimea.

items.synopsis: Many Australian retirees are returning to the workforce these days. For some, it's out of necessity; for others, it's for more philosophical reasons.

title.children: 'Who the hell am I now?': Meet one of the many Australians joining the great unretirement

image.altText: A baby sitting up, smiling, with a book in her hands.

items.synopsis: Prader-Willi Syndrome is experienced primarily as an insatiable and dangerous hunger. But parents and advocates say the reality of the condition is far more complex.

title.children: There's more to 'smiley' Evie's syndrome than an insatiable, life-threatening hunger

image.altText: An older man is carried on a stretcher past a train by men wearing military helmets and vests.

items.synopsis: Moscow steps up strikes on Ukraine as Kyiv prepares for a counteroffensive in which it is expected to try to retake occupied territory in the Kherson region.

title.children: Russia says United States ordered Ukrainian 'drone strike' on Kremlin, as 23 die in Kherson

image.altText: An illustration of a woman's profile with a squiggly line where her brain is. She's surrounded by water

items.synopsis: Menopause marks the end of a woman's reproductive stage, but it can also spell the beginning of changes in the way we think and feel. So how does oestrogen affect the brain?

title.children: Irritable? Teary? Anxious? How menopause can affect how we think and feel

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

items.synopsis: Australian shares are set to open lower in the wake of US markets falling on the back of growing concerns about the banking sector. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to drop, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

schema.headline: Live: ASX set to drop, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Apple sales down, just not by as much as analysts expected
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Apple reported quarterly revenue and profit above Wall Street's expectations, with iPhone sales rising and wearables sales slipping less than analysts expected. Apple said sales for its fiscal second quarter ended April 1 fell 2.5 per cent to $US94.84 billion. That was better than analyst expectations of a 4.4 per cent decline to $93 billion, according to data from Refinitiv. Profit was flat at $1.52 per share, compared with estimates of a 5.7 pe cent fall to $1.43 per share, according to Refinitiv data. Apple shares were up 1.6 per cent in after-hours trading. The broader consumer electronics industry is grappling with a decline in sales of smartphones, tablets and PCs as consumers and businesses who bought up electronics during the pandemic, tighten spending amid rising interest rates and economic uncertainty. Apple also held its dividend and stock buyback programs roughly in line with its last update to them a year ago, approving $90 billion in additional buybacks. Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company had set a fiscal second-quarter record for iPhone sales, thanks in part to picking up new users in markets such as India. "We were thrilled by our performance in emerging markets," Mr Cook said. "We set records for the iPhone installed base in every geographic segment, and we had very strong 'new to' (sales in) emerging markets, particularly in Brazil, India and Mexico." Mr Cook also said supply-chain snarls have vanished. "We had no material shortages at all during the quarter across any of the products," he said. However, sales of Macs fell more than 30 per cent sharply while iPad revenue slipped. Sales in China also dropped 2.9 per cent to $US17.8 billion, a slightly larger drop than overall revenue. IPhone sales rose 1.5% to $51.33 billion, compared with analyst expectations of a 3.3% decline to $48.9 billion, according to Refinitiv. Those results occurred against the backdrop of a 13 per cent. Sales in Apple's wearables business, which includes devices like AirPods and the Apple Watch, fell less than 1 per cent compared with estimates of a 4.4 per cent drop. Apple's biggest growth segment was its services business, which includes products like iCloud and Apple Pay, which grew 5.5 per cent to $20.9 billion, in line with analyst expectations. Mr Cook said Apple now has 975 million subscribers on its platform, which includes both Apple services and third-party apps, up from 935 million last quarter and an increase of 150 million from a year ago. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: EU hikes interest rates, signals more to come
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation. All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July. Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further. "We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference. "We know that we have more ground to cover." Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards. The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted could be the last in its own historic series of increases. The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade. This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Wall Street drops on banking worries
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: In the US, the benchmark S & P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061. It was its fourth-straight session of declines. The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127. The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector. PacWest's stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low. Western Alliance shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business. However, Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper. The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading. Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability. It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March. US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days, Reuters has reported. "Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said. "This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added. The KBW Regional Banking index dropped 3.3 per cent. Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S & P 500 Banks index falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent. The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the sell-off "overdone." PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year. - with Reuters

liveBlogUpdate.headline: It's Friday, and investors are getting worried about banks again
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Morning all. I'll be with you on the blog today. US stocks fell on fears about the banking sector. A California bank PacWest has been "assessing its options" including a possible sale. The ASX is set to drop at open. I'll have more financial news for you shortly.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: ASX set to drop, Wall Street down on renewed fears about global banking sector

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Apple sales down, just not by as much as analysts expected

children.content: Apple reported quarterly revenue and profit above Wall Street's expectations, with iPhone sales rising and wearables sales slipping less than analysts expected.

Apple said sales for its fiscal second quarter ended April 1 fell 2.5 per cent to $US94.84 billion. That was better than analyst expectations of a 4.4 per cent decline to $93 billion, according to data from Refinitiv.
Profit was flat at $1.52 per share, compared with estimates of a 5.7 pe cent fall to $1.43 per share, according to Refinitiv data.
Apple shares were up 1.6 per cent in after-hours trading.

The broader consumer electronics industry is grappling with a decline in sales of smartphones, tablets and PCs as consumers and businesses who bought up electronics during the pandemic, tighten spending amid rising interest rates and economic uncertainty.
Apple also held its dividend and stock buyback programs roughly in line with its last update to them a year ago, approving $90 billion in additional buybacks.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company had set a fiscal second-quarter record for iPhone sales, thanks in part to picking up new users in markets such as India.
"We were thrilled by our performance in emerging markets," Mr Cook said.
"We set records for the iPhone installed base in every geographic segment, and we had very strong 'new to' (sales in) emerging markets, particularly in Brazil, India and Mexico."
Mr Cook also said supply-chain snarls have vanished.
"We had no material shortages at all during the quarter across any of the products," he said.
However, sales of Macs fell more than 30 per cent sharply while iPad revenue slipped.
Sales in China also dropped 2.9 per cent to $US17.8 billion, a slightly larger drop than overall revenue.
IPhone sales rose 1.5% to $51.33 billion, compared with analyst expectations of a 3.3% decline to $48.9 billion, according to Refinitiv.
Those results occurred against the backdrop of a 13 per cent.
Sales in Apple's wearables business, which includes devices like AirPods and the Apple Watch, fell less than 1 per cent compared with estimates of a 4.4 per cent drop.
Apple's biggest growth segment was its services business, which includes products like iCloud and Apple Pay, which grew 5.5 per cent to $20.9 billion, in line with analyst expectations.

Mr Cook said Apple now has 975 million subscribers on its platform, which includes both Apple services and third-party apps, up from 935 million last quarter and an increase of 150 million from a year ago.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation. All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July. Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further. "We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference. "We know that we have more ground to cover." Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards. The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted could be the last in its own historic series of increases. The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade. This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes. - with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EU hikes interest rates, signals more to come

children.content: The European Central Bank slowed the pace of its interest rate increases on Thursday but signalled more tightening to come in what markets expect to be the final stage of its fight against inflation.
All ECB policymakers but one, Austria's Robert Holzmann, supported
the 25-basis-point increase in the ECB's main deposit rate to 3.25 per cent, which follows a series of 75 and 50-basis-point increases since last July.
Inflation across the 20 countries that share the euro is still stubbornly high and the ECB was at pains to say that borrowing costs would have to rise further.
"We are not pausing — that is very clear," ECB president Christine Lagarde told a press conference.
"We know that we have more ground to cover."

Ms Lagarde added that interest rates were not yet "sufficiently restrictive" to get inflation down to the ECB's 2 per cent target and made reference to future "policy decisions", suggesting that more than one additional rate rise could be on the cards.
The ECB's shift in gear came just a day after the US Federal Reserve also raised its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, which it hinted
could be the last in its own historic series of increases.
The slowdown in the pace of monetary policy tightening comes only days after euro zone banking data showed the biggest drop in demand for loans in over a decade.

This suggests that previous rate rises are being transmitted "forcefully" to the economy but with the usual lags, the ECB said, a comment economists took as a key justification for slowing the pace of hikes.
- with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the US, the benchmark S & P 500 declined 0.7 per cent to end the session at 4,061. It was its fourth-straight session of declines. The Nasdaq declined 0.5 per cent to 11,966, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.9 per cent to 33,127. The sell-off came as fears grew about the strength of the US banking sector. PacWest's stock slumped more than 40 per cent in afternoon trading, dropping to a record low. Western Alliance shares pared losses after plummeting by nearly 60 per cent following a Financial Times report that the lender was exploring strategic options, including a potential sale of all or part of its business. However, Western Alliance denied the report, calling it "categorically false in all respects", and said it was weighing legal options against the newspaper. The bank's stock was down nearly 35 per cent in afternoon trading. Western Alliance has been seeking to reassure investors about its financial stability. It comes as First Republic's collapse, the third major casualty of the biggest crisis to hit the US banking sector since 2008, rekindled a slide in shares of regional lenders this week despite regulatory efforts to staunch the turmoil that began with the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank in March. US officials at the federal and state levels are assessing the possibility of "market manipulation" behind big moves in banking share prices in recent days, Reuters has reported. "Nobody knows where these banks should be trading at because what we saw with Silicon Valley Bank is that the fundamentals can change so quickly," Tom Plumb, portfolio manager at Plumb Balanced Fund said. "This normally would have been a great opportunity to buy banks with premier regional presence and it may be, but the real concern is nobody knows what the rules are and what they are valued at," Mr Plumb added. The KBW Regional Banking index dropped 3.3 per cent. Major U.S. banks were also losing ground on Thursday, with the S & P 500 Banks index falling nearly 3 per cent. JPMorgan's shares fell 1.4 per cent, while Bank of America declined 3 per cent. The common theme among the banking stocks that have sold off sharply is that they reported large deposit declines in the first quarter, said Truist Securities analyst Brandon King, while calling the sell-off "overdone." PacWest Bancorp reported a loss of $1.1 billion attributed to shareholders for the first quarter of the year. - with Reuters

image.altText: Aerial image of a series of lush green islands in a blue ocean. Clouds meet the horizon.

items.synopsis: Beautiful places and friendly faces have long been the selling point of Pacific tourism. But after the closure of international borders during the pandemic, environmental concerns are causing Pacific countries to resist a return to mass tourism.

title.children: Craving a Pacific Island getaway? Here's why locals are pushing for more sustainable travel

image.altText: Jack Haig rides his bike

items.synopsis: The defending champion, Australia's Jai Hindley, will not be racing, but there's still plenty of interest in the first grand tour of this cycling season, the 106th edition of the Giro d'Italia.

title.children: The world champion looking to end a 51-year drought at the Giro d'Italia

image.altText: A tight head shot of an Aboriginal woman with dyed blonde hair.

items.synopsis: Margaret Hawke will learn of her punishment today for the murder of her three children, just hours after seeking support, in a tragedy prompting calls for more mining revenue to be channelled back into the Port Hedland community.

title.children: As a mother awaits sentencing for killing her children, her town wants help to stop future tragedies

image.altText: A police cordon and police car out the front of a suburban Darwin home

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Police say they are treating the death of Md Ishaqur Rahman Sifat, 23, as a homicide. A man remains in custody but has not been charged.

title.children: International student dies in Darwin hospital after violent home invasion

image.altText: Mushrooms glowing green in the dark

items.synopsis: Recent sightings mark the beginning of the mushroom season but the NSW Poisons Information Centre warns it is also the time of year when it receives a spike in calls.

title.children: Ghost mushrooms inspire awe in Sydney but poisons centre warns against foraging

image.altText: Victorian power - Snowy Hydro

items.synopsis: A bitter rift between the former boss of state-owned power provider Snowy Hydro and federal Energy Minister Chris Bowen has widened following claims Labor's green energy plans are not achievable.

title.children: Fuse blown as former Snowy Hydro boss takes aim at 'bulls**t' renewable energy goals

image.altText: Katy Gallagher wearing a black jacket and purple top, looking to the right

items.synopsis: A series of parliamentary inquiries found the mutual obligations element of the program to be punitive and "akin to coercive control".

title.children: Federal government to abolish 'polarising' ParentsNext scheme

image.altText: A goat eats the leaf from a weed.

items.synopsis: An increasing number of landowners and councils, along with the New South Wales Rural Fire Service, are using goats in the battle against invasive plant species.

title.children: Why goats are proving to be environmentally friendly weedbusters

image.altText: Ms Lamb sits in a wheelchair and looks over her fence towards the camera.

items.synopsis: As talks about how to make the NDIS more sustainable ramp up again, people with disability say a good place to start would be with the costly and "exhausting" red tape.

title.children: Rayna needed a new wheelchair cushion. It cost $1,000 just to get the NDIS forms filled out

image.altText: Penny Wong smiling, wearing a flower crown and lei over formal clothing

items.synopsis: A wide-ranging Pacific assistance package covering environmental, military, and economic support for Australia's closest neighbours will be unveiled in Tuesday's budget.

title.children: Australia to increase Pacific engagement with multi-million-dollar 'whole of government' budget package

image.altText: Prime Minister Kalsakau and Penny Wong sign a security agreement

items.synopsis: Anxieties are growing in Canberra that a landmark security agreement between Australia and Vanuatu could stall in the Pacific nation's parliament.

title.children: Concerns Vanuatu's parliament may refuse to ratify important security pact with Australia

image.altText: Five people sitting in the jury dock, an old woman in a tie dye tshirt at the centre clapping

items.synopsis: The comedy series has a crazy premise - an entirely fake court case where everyone involved is an actor except one sweet schmuck - but the result is funny and unexpectedly moving.

title.children: Why the internet is going gaga for 'fake doco' Jury Duty and lovable protagonist Ronald Gladden

image.altText: A large man wearing a suit and tie looks serious as he walks along.

items.synopsis: The disgraced former basketball star has admitted to raping the woman in two incidents, one of which allegedly left her in hospital with "life threatening" injuries.

title.children: Disgraced former basketball player 'Tiny' Pinder admits raping woman, in alleged 'life-threatening' incident

image.altText: A still from the show compared to a portrait of Queen Charlotte where both women are in similar outfits with blue hats.

items.synopsis: Bridgerton is back in the cultural zeitgeist thanks to its new prequel charting the rise to prominence and power of Queen Charlotte. But just how much of the show is true to life?

title.children: The new Bridgerton prequel is 'fiction inspired by fact'. So who was the real Queen Charlotte?

image.altText: Proud Boys chairman Enrique Tarrio at a far-right rally.

items.synopsis: A jury has convicted four members of the far-right Proud Boys militia group, finding they plotted to attack the US Capitol in a failed bid to block Congress from certifying President Joe Biden's 2021 election victory.

title.children: Jury convicts Proud Boys members of seditious conspiracy in US Capitol attack

image.altText: Singer Ed Sheeran smiles while speaking to the media outside a Manhattan court.

items.synopsis: British pop superstar Ed Sheeran's 2014 hit Thinking Out Loud did not unlawfully copy Marvin Gaye's classic 1973 song Let's Get It On, a Manhattan jury decides.

title.children: US jury sides with Ed Sheeran in Let's Get It On copyright trial

image.altText: A woman stands in flood water next to debris.

items.synopsis: Flooding and landslides kill at least 129 people in Rwanda and six in Uganda, as rescuers search for survivors.

title.children: Flooding, landslides kill at least 135 in Rwanda and Uganda

image.altText: South Indian men stand in a circle around a bonfire at night on city street

items.synopsis: Police say two gunmen entered a school near the Afghan border and opened fire, in the latest violence between Sunni and Shiite Muslims.

title.children: Five teachers killed in Pakistan school shooting as sectarian tensions boil over

image.altText: A man walking in a suit outside court

items.synopsis: Adam Cranston is one of five people found guilty of two charges over various roles in the Plutus Payroll scam, which ran for about three years to 2017.

title.children: Judge 'flabbergasted' legal aid pulled for one of architects of $105m tax fraud

image.altText: Two men smile in an image composite.

items.synopsis: One of two police officers attacked and stabbed in SA's Mid North has been discharged from hospital while the other is showing "positive progress" following surgery for critical injuries last night, the state's police commissioner says.

title.children: Stabbed SA policeman discharged from hospital, other showing 'positive progress' following surgery

image.altText: Juma and Zackaria Chol wear sunglasses. they are photographed in prison

items.synopsis: Sudanese-born men and women are estimated to make up about 10 per cent of people held in Australia's immigration detention facilities, and for most of them, there's little hope of leaving the gated compounds.

title.children: As war rages in Sudan, refugees in immigration detention in Australia have little hope of leaving

image.altText: NRL team mascots in the Brisbane CBD

items.synopsis: The city gets $30 million in kickbacks for tackling the logistical nightmare that is eight NRL games in three days at one stadium. Several states have approached the NRL for hosting rights.

title.children: Other states want it – so why is Brisbane fighting so hard to keep Magic Round in Queensland?
